title: Lab to determine the coefficient of friction

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Students are going to perform an experiment to determine the coefficient of kinetic friction, <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the lab using the setup shown. They are expected to find <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup as shown, which includes a two-block system with masses, <math alttext="Uppercase m sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Uppercase m sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>; a set of objects of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, which can be placed on the pegs on either block; and a very light string. There is non-negligible friction between block <math alttext="uppecase m sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and the table and the pulley has negligible mass and negligible friction. (a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

Students are going to perform an experiment to determine the coefficient of kinetic friction, <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the lab using the setup shown. They are expected to find <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup as shown, which includes a two-block system with masses, <math alttext="Uppercase m sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Uppercase m sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>; a set of objects of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, which can be placed on the pegs on either block; and a very light string. There is non-negligible friction between block <math alttext="uppecase m sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and the table and the pulley has negligible mass and negligible friction. (a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Briefly describe the procedure to be used to determine the coefficient of kinetic friction <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in the table and be sure to use the equipment you identified in part (a).

(c) Which quantities would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the coefficient of kinetic friction, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine the coefficient of kinetic friction, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) In a second experiment students replace the pulley with a wheel that has non-negligible mass of <math alttext="uppercase m sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and radius <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. When the blocks are released, will the magnitude of the tension in the horizontal part of the string, <math alttext="t sub h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> , be greater than, less than, or equal to the magnitude of the tension in the vertical part of the string, <math alttext="t sub v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Assume that the blocks always get into motion once released.

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
